title.narrative: Land Conflict Resolution in Koh Kong

participating-org.narrative: The Community Legal Education Centre (CLEC) was created in 1996 as legal resource centre, promoting the rule of law, justice and democracy in Cambodia. From 1996 to 2001 CLEC operated as an arm of the University of the San Francisco School of Law, fundedby USAID.In December 2001, CLEC became a local NGO officially registered with Ministry of the Interior. Since its establishment CLEC has taught over five thousand Cambodians in different subjects of law through its 'certificate in law' program. CLEC hasalso produced a legal text-book series, which represents some of the only Cambodian legal texts on a wide range of subjects. CLEC program activities combine legal education, empowerment and advocacy. Its training courses are designed for a wide range oftarget groups, including localcommunities, civil society organisations, NGOs and government officials. CLEC has been involved in advocacy on a number of significant law reform issues, including: the 2001 Land Law, the sub-decree on indigenous communal land titling, the establishment of the Arbitration Council, the election dispute resolution process, the draft Peaceful Assembly Law, and commentary and review of numerous pieces of legislation. Since 2004, CLEC has also embarked on a major project of high-impact public interest legal advocacy, particularly in the areas of land and natural resources. The organisation is organised in four main program units: the Labour Program, the Access to Justice Program and Community Justice Project; the Land and NaturalResource Program; and the Good Governance Program

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
